'''Winifred Margaret Deans''' (9 October 1901 – 7 June 1990) was a prolific translator of German scientific texts into English, who also taught mathematics and physics to secondary schoolchildren and worked at the Commonwealth Bureau of Animal Nutrition.<ref name="“primesrc">{{cite web|title=Deans’ Biography|url=http://www-history.mcs.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Deans.html|publisher=University of St Andrews, Scotland|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref>
== Life and education == Deans was one of two siblings, born to Duncan Deans and Mary Ann Sharp, in [[New Milton]], [[Hampshire]], [[United Kingdom]]. She graduated with an M.A. with First Class Honours in Mathematics from the [[University of Aberdeen]] in 1922. She also obtained a B. Sc. from the same university in 1923. She later studied at [[Newnham College, Cambridge]], obtaining a First Class B.A. after she took Part I of the [[Mathematical Tripos]] in 1925. She earned another M.A, from Cambridge, in 1929.<ref name="“family">{{cite web|title=History of Sharp Family of Aberdeenshire|url=http://www.carsontree.talktalk.net/Sharp/Sharp.htm|publisher=Robert Carson|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref>
Deans won several awards in the course of her education, the University of Aberdeen awarding her the Simpson mathematical prize and the [[Neil Arnott]] prize for experimental physics in 1921; she also stood first in the examination for the Greig prize in natural philosophy.<ref name="“aurvw">{{cite web|title=The Internet Archive's copy of Aberdeen University Review Vol IX|url=https://archive.org/stream/aberdeenuniversi09univuoft#page/264/mode/2up|publisher=Aberdeen University Press|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref>
== Work == Deans taught mathematics and physics at the Harrow County Secondary School for Girls for two years. She then returned to Aberdeen and received a Diploma in Education in 1927. She joined [[Blackie and Son]], a publishing house in [[Glasgow]] as an Assistant Science Editor. She began translating German publications, primarily related to Physics and Mathematics, for them. Important translations included those of texts by [[Max Born]], [[Léon Brillouin]], [[Louis de Broglie]], [[Peter Debye]], [[Richard Gans]], [[Robert Pohl]] and [[Erwin Schrödinger]]. She also translated Else Wegener and Fritz Loewe's chronicle of [[Alfred Wegener]]’s fourth expedition to Greenland, undertaken in 1930–31.
Deans joined the Commonwealth Bureau of Animal Nutrition which was part of the [[Rowett Research Institute]], Aberdeen, in 1945. She retired from the bureau in 1966.
Deans’ library and personal papers were given to the University of Aberdeen, and can now be found in their Special Collections, Library and Archives.
== Translations == * With J F Shearer: ''Collected Papers on Wave Mechanics'', E Schrödinger, translated in 1928<ref name="“trschrdngr">{{cite book|last=Schrodinger|first=Erwin|title=Collected Papers on Wave Mechanics|year=1928|publisher=Blackie and Son|location=Glasgow|isbn=9780821835241}}</ref> * ''Selected Papers on Wave Mechanics'', L de Broglie and L Brillouin, translated in 1928 * ''Alpine Flowers: The Most Common Alpine Plants of Switzerland, Austria and Bavaria'', G Hegi, translated in 1930<ref name="“trhegi">{{cite web|title=WorldCat page on Alpine Flowers|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/alpine-flowers-the-most-common-alpine-plants-of-switzerland-austria-and-bavaria/oclc/742457703|publisher=WorldCat|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref> * ''The Dipole Moment and Chemical Structure'', P Debye, translated in 1931<ref name="“trdipole">{{cite web|title=Wiley abstract of the review of The Dipole Moment and Chemical Structure|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jctb.5000504416/abstract|publisher=Journal of Chemical Technology and Biotechnology|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref> * ''The Interference of Electrons'', P Debye, translated in 1931<ref name="“trelctrns">{{cite web|title=IberLibro page on The Interference of Electrons|url=http://www.iberlibro.com/interference-electrons-Authorized-translation-Winifred-Deans/16806530054/bd|publisher=IberLibro|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref> * ''Vector Analysis and Applications to Physics'', R Gans, translated in 1932<ref name="“trgans">{{cite book|last=Gans|first=Richard|title=Vector Analysis and Applications to Physics|year=1932|publisher=Blackie and Son|location=Glasgow|isbn=9781114524620}}</ref> * ''Physical Principles of Mechanics and Acoustics'', R Pohl, translated in 1932 * ''The Structure of Molecules'', P Debye, translated in 1932 * ''The Restless Universe'', M Born, translated in 1935 * ''The Cave Children'', A T Sonnleitner, translated in 1935<ref name="“trcave">{{cite web|title=Amazon.com page on The Cave Children|url=https://www.amazon.com/Cave-Children-Th-Sonnleitner/dp/B001P1P9GI|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref> * With J Dougall: ''The Physics of Solids and Fluids'', P P Ewald, T Poschl and L Prandtl, translated in 1936<ref name="“trewld">{{cite web|title=WorldCat page on The Physics of Solids and Fluids|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/physics-of-solids-and-fluids-by-pp-ewald-th-poschl-and-l-prandtl-authorized-translation-by-j-dougall-and-wm-deans-second-edition/oclc/800888560|publisher=WorldCat|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref> * ''Greenland Journey'', E Wegener and F Loewe, translated in 1939 * ''Hinterland Liberia'', E Becker-Donner, translated in 1939<ref name="“trdnnr">{{cite web|title=Clevnet page on Hinterland Liberia|url=http://clevnet.library.link/portal/Hinterland-Liberia-by-Etta-Donner.-Translated-by/myV77yT7aZg/|publisher=Cleveland Public Library|accessdate=26 Aug 2016}}</ref>

{|class="wikitable" bgcolor="#ffffff" cellpadding="5" align="right" style="margin-left:10px" width="240" !bgcolor=#e7dcc3 colspan=2|Witting polytope |- align=center |colspan=2|[[File:Witting_polytope.png|320px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Schläfli symbol]]||<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub> |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Coxeter diagram]]||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}} |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Cells||240 [[Hessian polyhedron|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] [[File:Complex polyhedron 3-3-3-3-3.png|60px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Faces||2160 [[Möbius–Kantor polygon|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] [[File:Complex polygon 3-3-3.png|40px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Edges||2160 [[trion (geometry)|<sub>3</sub>{}]] [[File:Complex trion.png|30px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Vertices||240 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Petrie polygon]]||30-gon |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[van Oss polygon]]||90 <sub>3</sub>{4}<sub>3</sub> [[File:Complex polygon 3-4-3.png|60px]] |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Shephard group]]||L<sub>4</sub> = <sub>3</sub>[3]<sub>3</sub>[3]<sub>3</sub>[3]<sub>3</sub>, order 155,520 |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|[[Dual polyhedron]]||Self-dual |- |bgcolor=#e7dcc3|Properties||Regular |} In 4-dimensional complex [[geometry]], the '''Witting polytope''' is a [[regular complex polytope]], named as: <sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}. It has 240 vertices, 2160 <sub>3</sub>{} edges, 2160 [[Möbius–Kantor polygon|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] faces, and 240 [[Hessian polyhedron|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] cells. It is self-dual. Each vertex belongs to 27 edges, 72 faces, and 27 cells, corresponding to the [[Hessian polyhedron]] [[vertex figure]].
== Symmetry== Its symmetry by <sub>3</sub>[3]<sub>3</sub>[3]<sub>3</sub>[3]<sub>3</sub> or {{CDD|3node|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}, order 155,520.<ref>Coxeter Regular Convex Polytopes, 12.5 The Witting polytope</ref> It has 240 copies of {{CDD|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}, order 648 at each cell.<ref>Coxeter, Complex Regular Polytopes, p.134</ref>
== Structure== The [[Configuration (polytope)|configuation matrix]] is:<ref>Coxeter, Complex Regular polytopes, p.132</ref> <math>\left [\begin{smallmatrix}240&27&72&27\\3&2160&8&8\\8&8&2160&3\\27&72&27&240\end{smallmatrix}\right ]</math>
The number of vertices, edges, faces, and cells are seen in the diagonal of the matrix. These are computed by the order of the group divided by the order of the subgroup, by removing certain complex reflections, shown with X below. The number of elements of the k-faces are seen in rows below the diagonal. The number of elements in the vertex figure, etc, are given in rows above the digonal. {| class=wikitable !L<sub>4</sub>||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}} ! [[k-face|''k''-face]]||f<sub>k</sub>||f<sub>0</sub>||f<sub>1</sub>||f<sub>2</sub>||f<sub>3</sub>||[[vertex figure|''k''-figure]] !Notes |- align=right |L<sub>3</sub> ||{{CDD|node_x|2|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}||( ) !f<sub>0</sub> |BGCOLOR="#ffe0e0"|'''240'''||27||72||27|| [[Hessian polyhedron|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]]|| L<sub>4</sub>/L<sub>3</sub> = 216*6!/27/4! = 240 |- align=right |rowspan=2|L<sub>2</sub>L<sub>1</sub> ||{{CDD|3node_1|2|node_x|2|3node|3|3node}}|| <sub>3</sub>{ } !f<sub>1</sub> ||3||BGCOLOR="#ffffe0"|'''2160'''||8||8|| [[Möbius–Kantor polygon|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] ||rowspan=2| L<sub>4</sub>/L<sub>2</sub>L<sub>1</sub> = 216*6!/4!/3 = 2160 |- align=right ||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|2|node_x|2|3node}}|| [[Möbius–Kantor polygon|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] !f<sub>2</sub> ||8||8||BGCOLOR="#e0ffe0"|'''2160'''||3|| <sub>3</sub>{ } |- align=right ||L<sub>3</sub> ||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|2|node_x}}|| [[Hessian polyhedron|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] !f<sub>3</sub> ||27||72||27||BGCOLOR="#e0ffff"|'''240'''|| ( ) || L<sub>4</sub>/L<sub>3</sub> = 216*6!/27/4! = 240 |}
== Coordinates== Its 240 vertices are given coordinates in <math>\mathbb{C}^4</math>: {| class=wikitable | : (0, ±ω<sup>μ</sup>, -±ω<sup>ν</sup>, ±ω<sup>λ</sup>) : (-±ω<sup>μ</sup>, 0, ±ω<sup>ν</sup>, ±ω<sup>λ</sup>) : (±ω<sup>μ</sup>, -±ω<sup>ν</sup>, 0, ±ω<sup>λ</sup>) : (-±ω<sup>λ</sup>, -±ω<sup>μ</sup>, -±ω<sup>ν</sup>, 0) | : (±ω<sup>λ</sup>√3, 0, 0, 0) : (0, ±ω<sup>λ</sup>√3, 0, 0) : (0, 0, ±ω<sup>λ</sup>√3, 0) : (0, 0, 0, ±ω<sup>λ</sup>√3) |}
where <math>\omega = \tfrac{-1+i\sqrt3}{2}, \lambda, \nu, \mu = 0,1,2</math>.
The last 6 points form hexagonal ''holes'' on one of its 40 diameters. There are 40 [[hyperplane]]s contain central [[Hessian polyhedron#Related complex polyhedra|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{4}<sub>2</sub>]], {{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|4|node}} figures, with 72 vertices.
== Witting configuration == Coxeter named it after [[Alexander Witting]] for being a ''Witting [[Configuration (polytope)|configuration]]'' in complex projective 3-space:<ref>Alexander Witting, Ueber Jacobi'sche Functionen k<sup>ter</sup> Ordnung Zweier Variabler, Mathemematische Annalen 29 (1887), 157-70, see especially p.169</ref> :<math>\left [\begin{smallmatrix} 40&12&12\\2&240&2\\12&12&40 \end{smallmatrix}\right ]</math> or <math>\left [\begin{smallmatrix} 40&9&12\\4&90&4\\12&9&40 \end{smallmatrix}\right ]</math>
The Witting configuration is related to the finite space PG(3,2<sup>2</sup>), consisting of 85 points, 357 lines, and 85 planes.<ref>Coxeter, Complex regular polytopes, p.133</ref>
== Related real polytope== Its 240 vertices are shared with the real 8-dimensional polytope [[4 21 polytope|4<sub>21</sub>]], {{CDD|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|branch|3a|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|nodea_1}}. Its 2160 3-edges are sometimes drawn as 6480 simple edges, slightly less than the 6720 edges of 4<sub>21</sub>. The 240 difference is accounted by 40 central hexagons in 4<sub>21</sub> whose edges are not included in <sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>.<ref>Coxeter, Complex Regular Polytopes, p.134</ref>
== The honeycomb of Witting polytopes ==
The regular Witting polytope has one further stage as a [[Complex_polytope#Regular_complex_4-apeirotopes|4-dimensional honeycomb]], {{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}. It has the Witting polytope as both its facets, and vertex figure. It is self-dual, and its dual coincides with itself.<ref>Coxeter, Complex Regular Polytopes, p.135</ref>
Hyperplane sections of this honeycomb include 3-dimensional honeycombs {{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|4|node}}.
The honeycomb of Witting polytopes has a real representation as the 8-dimensional polytope [[5 21 honeycomb|5<sub>21</sub>]], {{CDD|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|branch|3a|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|nodea|3a|nodea_1}}.
Its [[f-vector]] element counts are in proportion: 1, 80, 270, 80, 1.<ref>Coxeter Regular Convex Polytopes, 12.5 The Witting polytope</ref> The [[Configuration (polytope)|configuration matrix]] for the honeycomb is: {| class=wikitable !L<sub>5</sub>||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}} ! [[k-face|''k''-face]]||f<sub>k</sub>||f<sub>0</sub>||f<sub>1</sub>||f<sub>2</sub>||f<sub>3</sub>||f<sub>4</sub>||[[vertex figure|''k''-figure]] !Notes |- align=right |L<sub>4</sub> ||{{CDD|node_x|2|3node|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}||( ) !f<sub>0</sub> |BGCOLOR="#ffe0e0"|'''N'''||240||2160||2160||240 || <sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>|| L<sub>5</sub>/L<sub>4</sub> = '''N''' |- align=right |L<sub>3</sub>L<sub>1</sub> ||{{CDD|3node_1|2|node_x|2|3node|3|3node|3|3node}}|| <sub>3</sub>{ } !f<sub>1</sub> ||3||BGCOLOR="#ffffe0"|'''80N'''||27||72||27|| [[Hessian polyhedron|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] || L<sub>5</sub>/L<sub>3</sub>L<sub>1</sub> = 80'''N''' |- align=right |L<sub>2</sub>L<sub>2</sub>||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|2|node_x|2|3node|3|3node}}|| [[Möbius–Kantor polygon|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] !f<sub>2</sub> ||8||8||BGCOLOR="#e0ffe0"|'''270N'''||8||8|| [[Möbius–Kantor polygon|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] || L<sub>5</sub>/L<sub>2</sub>L<sub>2</sub> = 270'''N''' |- align=right ||L<sub>3</sub>L<sub>1</sub> ||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|2|node_x|2|3node}}|| [[Hessian polyhedron|<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>]] !f<sub>3</sub> ||27||72||27||BGCOLOR="#e0ffff"|'''80N'''||3|| <sub>3</sub>{} || L<sub>5</sub>/L<sub>3</sub>L<sub>1</sub> = 80'''N''' |- align=right ||L<sub>4</sub> ||{{CDD|3node_1|3|3node|3|3node|3|3node|2|node_x}}|| <sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub>{3}<sub>3</sub> !f<sub>4</sub> ||240||2160||2160||240|| BGCOLOR="#ffe0ff"|'''N''' || ( ) || L<sub>5</sub>/L<sub>4</sub> = '''N''' |}
